Instruction:
Task Description: Implement a TCP server in Go that can handle multiple client connections concurrently, with support for both plain TCP and TLS-secured connections. The server should manage connection timeouts, track active connections, and provide hooks for custom message handling.

Struct Description: The Server struct represents a TCP server that can listen for incoming connections, handle them concurrently, and manage server lifecycle operations. It supports both plain TCP and TLS configurations.

Fields:

Addr: string - The network address to listen on (e.g., ":8080")
Net: string - The network type (tcp, tcp4, tcp6, or their TLS variants)
Listener: net.Listener - The active network listener
TLSConfig: *tls.Config - Configuration for TLS connections
PacketConn: net.PacketConn - UDP connection handler (unused in TCP implementation)
Handler: Handler - Interface for handling incoming messages
ReadTimeout: time.Duration - Maximum duration for reading a request
WriteTimeout: time.Duration - Maximum duration for writing a response
IdleTimeout: func() time.Duration - Function returning idle connection timeout
MsgAcceptFunc: MsgAcceptFunc - Function to filter acceptable messages
lock: sync.RWMutex - Mutex for protecting concurrent access to server state
started: bool - Flag indicating if server is running
shutdown: chan struct{} - Channel for shutdown signaling
conns: map[net.Conn]struct{} - Map of active connections
udpPool: sync.Pool - Pool for UDP resources (unused in TCP implementation)

Methods:

ListenAndServe() error - Starts the server and begins accepting connections
serveTCP(net.Listener) error - Internal method to handle TCP connections
serveTCPConn(*sync.WaitGroup, net.Conn) - Handles an individual TCP connection
isStarted() bool - Helper method to check server running state
init() - Initializes server internal structures
getReadTimeout() time.Duration - Gets the current read timeout value
